regulatorySummary.purpose: The purpose of the amendments to the SEPA Regulation is to enhance the efficiency and security of payment systems within the EU by promoting the adoption of instant credit transfers in euro. This initiative aims to ensure that instant payments become a standard offering across payment service providers, thereby improving transaction speeds and supporting the digital economy.
regulatorySummary.scope: The amendments apply to all payment service providers operating within the EU, requiring them to offer instant credit transfer services alongside traditional credit transfer services. The regulation covers both national and cross-border credit transfers in euro, aiming to standardize the execution time and charges associated with these transactions.
regulatorySummary.relevance: The relevance of these regulatory changes is particularly significant for financial institutions that engage in high volumes of euro-denominated transactions. By mandating the provision of instant credit transfers, the regulation seeks to enhance the competitiveness of European financial markets and improve the overall user experience for consumers and businesses.

impactAssessment.introduction: The proposed amendments to the SEPA Regulation are expected to have a profound impact on various aspects of financial operations, from transaction processing speeds to the competitive landscape of payment services within the EU.

affectedAreas.impact: The requirement for payment service providers to offer instant credit transfers will necessitate significant infrastructural upgrades and adjustments in operational procedures to handle real-time transaction processing and compliance with enhanced security measures.

The availability of instant credit transfers is likely to raise client expectations regarding transaction speeds and service quality. Financial institutions will need to enhance client communication and support services to address these expectations effectively.
Instant credit transfers will require more dynamic liquidity management and forecasting models to manage the increased speed and frequency of transactions, impacting daily treasury operations.

The shift to instant credit transfers will increase the complexity of reconciliation processes, as financial institutions will need to ensure that their internal records are updated in real-time to reflect instant transactions accurately.

keyDates.event: Start of the evaluation period for the development of charges for payment accounts and credit transfers as stipulated by the SEPA Regulation.
Publication of Regulation (EU) 2024/886 amending SEPA Regulation regarding instant credit transfers in euro.
Publication of the Instant Payment Regulation (IPR) amending the SEPA Regulation.
Deadline for the European Commission to submit a report evaluating the impact of Article 5b(1) on charges for credit transfers.

regulatorySummary.purpose: The primary purpose of reforming the EU Benchmarks Regulation (BMR) is to address fundamental flaws that have positioned the regulation as a threat rather than a protective measure for benchmark users within the EU. The reform aims to align the BMR with global standards, ensuring that it provides proportionate protection to investors, imposes appropriate compliance burdens based on the significance of benchmarks, and maintains competitive fairness without unnecessary barriers.
regulatorySummary.scope: The scope of the proposed reforms is to narrow the mandatory compliance requirements to only systemic EU and third-country benchmarks. This shift aims to reduce the regulatory burden on less critical benchmarks, allowing for a voluntary compliance regime that encourages high standards without mandating them. The reform also seeks to enhance the visibility and accessibility of compliant benchmarks through improved registration and information dissemination processes.
regulatorySummary.relevance: The relevance of these reforms is significant in the context of global financial markets where benchmarks play a crucial role. By ensuring that the BMR is aligned with international practices, such as those adopted in the transition from LIBOR, the EU can protect its financial markets from disruptions caused by non-compliant benchmarks while fostering a competitive environment that is conducive to innovation and growth.

impactAssessment.introduction: The proposed reforms to the EU Benchmarks Regulation are expected to have a profound impact on various aspects of financial operations within the EU. By focusing compliance efforts on systemic benchmarks and introducing a voluntary regime for others, the reforms aim to streamline regulatory processes and reduce the burden on financial institutions.

affectedAreas.impact: The reform will likely reduce the compliance costs associated with managing benchmarks for liquidity and risk, allowing for more efficient capital deployment and potentially lower funding costs for the bank.

Enhanced visibility and accessibility of compliant benchmarks will improve the quality and reliability of client reports, particularly in performance and risk analytics, thereby boosting client trust and satisfaction.

The reforms will facilitate better risk mitigation by ensuring more reliable and compliant benchmarks are used for valuation and margin calculations, thus enhancing the stability of collateral management processes.
By clarifying the benchmarks that can be used and ensuring they meet high compliance standards, the reforms will reduce operational risks associated with settlement and custody services.
The use of compliant and transparent benchmarks will ensure that corporate actions related to securities indexed to these benchmarks are processed with greater accuracy and reduced risk of errors.

keyDates.event: Application of Regulation on Low Carbon Benchmarks
Amendment of BMR regarding third-country spot FX benchmarks
Scheduled end of transition period for third-country benchmarks
Potential further extension of the transition period for third-country benchmarks

regulatorySummary.purpose: The purpose of the Instant Payment Regulation (IPR) is to establish a framework for instant euro-denominated credit transfers across the European Union. This regulation aims to enhance the efficiency of payments within the EU by reducing the time it takes for transactions to be processed, thereby improving liquidity management and customer experience. It also seeks to foster innovation and competition among Payment Service Providers (PSPs) by standardizing the requirements for instant payments.
regulatorySummary.scope: The scope of the IPR includes all credit institutions within the EU that offer euro-denominated credit transfers. It mandates these institutions to provide instant payment services to their customers through all available channels. This regulation also covers the reporting requirements and operational standards that PSPs must adhere to, ensuring compliance with EU sanctions and other regulatory frameworks.
regulatorySummary.relevance: The relevance of the IPR is significant in the context of the digital transformation of the financial sector. By facilitating instant payments, the regulation supports the EU's broader objectives of creating a more integrated and efficient European payments market. It also addresses the need for rapid transaction processing which is critical in the modern economy where speed and efficiency are paramount.

impactAssessment.introduction: The introduction of the Instant Payment Regulation is expected to have a profound impact on various aspects of business operations for PSPs and financial institutions. This includes changes to payment processing systems, liquidity management, fraud detection, and compliance with regulatory standards.

affectedAreas.impact: The Payments lifecycle will undergo significant changes as PSPs will need to upgrade their systems to handle instant processing of transactions. This includes technical enhancements to support real-time data handling and integration with EU-wide instant payment platforms. Additionally, PSPs will face increased operational costs and will need to ensure their systems are robust enough to handle the higher volume of transactions without compromising on security.

Transaction Screening will be critically affected as PSPs must implement real-time screening of transactions to comply with EU sanctions and anti-money laundering regulations. This will require sophisticated technology to manage false positives and ensure legitimate transactions are not unduly delayed, balancing compliance with efficiency.

Under the IPR, PSPs are required to provide detailed reports on instant payment transactions, including volumes and values of transactions processed instantly. This will necessitate enhancements in data collection and reporting systems to ensure accuracy and timeliness of the information provided to clients and regulators.

Compliance monitoring will need to be intensified to ensure ongoing adherence to the new regulatory requirements introduced by the IPR. PSPs will need to continuously evaluate their compliance frameworks to address any discrepancies in real-time transaction processing and reporting.

Publication of the Instant Payment Regulation in the Official Journal of the European Union
